title: 105_hr1381
content: The text chunk "REVOLVING FUND" is a condensed summary of the previous paragraphs. The United States Institute for Environmental Conflict Resolution Revolving Fund is established in the Treasury, administered by the Foundation. It consists of appropriated amounts and funds from section 11. The Foundation will use the Revolving Fund for necessary expenses, including salaries, mediation services, and other reasonable costs. The Revolving Fund is separate from the Trust Fund and is not subject to certain program priorities. The Revolving Fund, separate from the Trust Fund, is used for necessary expenses determined by the Board. It is not subject to certain program priorities and can be invested in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The Revolving Fund can acquire obligations of the United States for investments, which can be sold at market price. Interest and proceeds from the obligations will be credited to the Revolving Fund. SEC. 7. USE OF THE INSTITUTE BY A FEDERAL AGENCY. The Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 is amended to include a new section allowing the use of the Institute by a federal agency. A Federal agency can utilize the Foundation and the Institute for assessment, mediation, or related services regarding environmental, public lands, or natural resource disputes. The agency can contract and pay for the Institute's services, with payments going into a Revolving Fund. Prior notification to the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality is required before using the Foundation or Institute for services. Before using the Foundation or Institute for services, a Federal agency must notify the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality. The notification should include details of the issues, parties involved, prior efforts to address the issues, and any other relevant information. In cases of disputes between agencies, concurrence is required. Amendments are made to the Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992, changing references from "Fund" to "Trust Fund" in various sections.
